ygData.subject: slashdot
ygData.msgSnippet: Hello all- Thanks to your help, CPPNs/HyperNEAT/EndlessForms were Slashdotted today! The EndlessForms.com server has been hammered, but so far has held up!

Hello all-

Thanks to your help, CPPNs/HyperNEAT/EndlessForms were Slashdot=
ted today! The EndlessForms.com server has been hammered, but so far has he=
ld up!  

http://tech.slashdot.org/story/11/09/24/0513236/crowdsourcing-spe=
eds-evolution-of-3d-printable-objects

Below is the blurb Jimmy Secretan po=
sted. The Slashdot editors cut the mention of the New Scientist print artic=
le (which is the one mostly focused on CPPNs/HyperNEAT), but they kept most=
 of the rest. :-)

EndlessForms.com uses evolutionary algorithms and crowds=
ourcing to design objects that can be 3D printed in materials such as silve=
r, steel or silicone. MIT's Technology Review [1] says "The rules EndlessFo=
rms uses to generate objects and their variants resemble those of developme=
ntal biology=97the study of how DNA instructions unfold to create an entire=
 living organism. =85The technology is 'very impressive,' says Neri Oxman, =
director of the MIT Media Lab's Mediated Matter research group. She believe=
s the user-friendliness of the evolutionary approach could help drive the b=
roader adoption of 3-D printing technologies, similar to how easy-to-use im=
age editors fueled the growth of digital photography and graphic manipulati=
on. Oxman [notes] that this could ultimately have an impact on design simil=
ar to the impact that blogs and social media have had on journalism, openin=
g the field to the general public." The New Scientist has a quick video [2]=
 tour and describes how the same technology can evolve complex, artificiall=
y intelligent brains and bodies for robots that can eventually be 3D printe=
d [3].

[1] http://www.technologyreview.com/computing/38433/page1/
[2] http=
://www.newscientist.com/blogs/onepercent/2011/08/evolve-your-own-objects-fo=
r-3d.html
[3] http://jeffclune.com/webfiles/press/Clune-NewScientist-Evolvi=
ngRobotBodiesAndBrains.pdf

There has been a lot of new shapes so far today=
, and they're still rolling in. 

Thanks very much to all who helped out!

=
Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Postdoctoral Fellow
Hod Lipson's Creative Machine=
s Laboratory
Cornell University
jeffclune@...
jeffclune.com


--Apple-Mail-9--703631951
